answers.body_markdown:
> Can I implement multiple Get methods in same controller?

Yes. They just need to have unique routes. (There might be some more nuance to that rule, but it's the broad advice).

> Is my Configure code to MapRoute correct?

Doesn't look like it. `GetByName` is the name of the _method_ not the route to the _action_. Actually the easiest thing to do is just not have any named routes at all in your Startup file:

    app.UseMvc(); // that's it.

> What URL should be to call GetByName (https://localhost:44306/api/Books/author=Smith) method?

Assuming the full class looks like this:

```
[Route("api/Books")]
public class Books
{
    [HttpGet("")]
    public ActionResult<IEnumerable<Book>> Get()

    [HttpGet("{name}")]
    public ActionResult<Book> GetByName([FromRoute] string name)   
}
```

Then to call the `Get` method you would call `/api/Books` and for the `GetByName` method you would call `/api/Books/abcd`.

> Is it normal to implement multiple GET,(POST) etc. methods in the same Controller?

Sure. Use controllers (in my opinion) to logically group similar endpoints by some criteria, usually by the resource type they interact with.

answers.body_markdown:
*`PostFields` is just a `typedef` for `cURLpp::OptionTrait<std::string, cURL::CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS>`, I'm simplifying things below.*

If you read the error messages carefully, they tell you exactly what is wrong:

> error: no matching function for call to 'curlpp::OptionTrait&lt;std::__cxx11::basic_string&lt;char>, CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS>::OptionTrait(std::__cxx11::list&lt;std::__cxx11::basic_string&lt;char> >&)'

What that is basically saying is that you can't pass a `std::list<std::string>` to the constructor of `PostFields`.  There are 4 candidate constructors reported in the error details, none of which take a `std::list` as input:

```c++
PostFields()
PostFields(const std::string&)
PostFields(const PostFields&)
PostFields(PostFields&&)
```

Indeed, if you read the [cURLpp documentation](https://github.com/jpbarrette/curlpp/blob/master/doc/guide.pdf), you can't create a `PostFields` from a `std::list`.  Which makes sense, per the [`cURL` documentation](https://curl.haxx.se/docs/) for [`CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS`](https://curl.haxx.se/libcurl/c/CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS.html):

> Pass a char * as parameter, pointing to the full data to send in an HTTP POST operation. You must make sure that the data is formatted the way you want the server to receive it. libcurl will not convert or encode it for you in any way. For example, the web server may assume that this data is url-encoded. 

`CURLOPT_POSTFIELDS` expects a single `char*` as input (which cURLpp wraps using `std::string`), so you have to pass your `PUT` data as a single url-encoded string, just like you do on the command line, eg:

```c++
request.setOpt(new curlpp::Options::PostFields("symbol=EB&side=ri&quantity=3"));
```

Where did you ever get the idea that you can use a `std::list` with `PostFields`?

---

BTW, per the cURLpp documentation, you do not really need to use `new` when adding options to the `curlpp::Easy` object:

```
curlpp::Easy request;
request.setOpt(curlpp::Options::Url(url));
request.setOpt(curlpp::Options::UserPwd("abc"));
request.setOpt(curlpp::Options::CustomRequest("PUT"));
request.setOpt(curlpp::Options::PostFields("symbol=EB&side=ri&quantity=3"));
```

answers.body_markdown:
Shutdowned state is irreversible, so just need to create a new executor if you need. There is no other way to reuse the previous one. But why do you need to shut it down if you're going to create it again? If it has too many tasks and you can sacrifice them in favor in new ones, then it makes sense to configure reasonable timeout for each task and configure the pool itself (for instance, pool and task queue size).

Each call of `Executor.schedule(() -> { doRealTask(); }, 0, TimeUnit.MICROSECONDS);` will return `ScheduledFuture` instance, you can store it and process the result later.

answers.body_markdown:
Here's a function that adds up to two zeros before numbers that come at the end of text. For example Boiler 1 will become Boiler 001 and Boiler 12 would become Boiler 012.

    CREATE FUNCTION [dbo].[sortTextWithNum](@text nvarchar(max))
    returns nvarchar(max) as 
    begin
    	declare @reverse nvarchar(max) = reverse(@text)
    	declare @numIndex int = patindex('%[^0-9]%', @reverse)
    	return iif(@numIndex=1, @text, substring(@text, 0, len(@text)-@numIndex+2) + format(cast(reverse(left(@reverse, @numIndex-1)) as int),'D3'))
    end

You can use it like this:

    select ControlName from [YourTable] order by dbo.sortTextWithNum(ControlName)

As the problem sits right now we want to sort by the last set of numbers if there are more than 1 set of number sections in the string. This code will do that. If there is only one set of numbers or even no numbers this works.

    declare @Something table
    (
    	ControlName varchar(50)

    , ('MAIN VALVE')
    , ('VALVE 10')
    , ('BOILER 2')
    , ('VALVE 17')
    , ('BOILER 1')
    , ('VALVE 19')
    , ('VALVE 2')
    
    select *
    from @Something
    order by left(ControlName, LEN(ControlName) - patindex('%[^0-9]%', REVERSE(ControlName)) + 1) --this gets the "prefix" or characters before the last set of numbers
    	, convert(int, right(ControlName, patindex('%[^0-9]%', REVERSE(ControlName)) - 1)) --this gets the last set of numbers

answers.body_markdown:
I think a simpler statement of the ordering is:

    select *
    from @something s
    order by left(ControlName, patindex('%[0-9]%', ControlName + '0') - 1),
             len(ControlName),
             ControlName

The order by keys do the following:

- Order by everything before the first number.
- Order by the length of the control name, so shorter numbers (`1`) are before larger numbers (`100`).
- Order by the name, so the numbers are in order.

You appear to have managed to change all pixels with index 20 into index 1 and all pixels with index 16 into 2. However, you then need to copy the palette entry 20 to palette entry 1 and palette entry 16 to palette entry 2 in order to make the colours remain the same.

So, you want:

    import numpy as np
    from PIL import Image

    # Load image
    im = Image.open('R0T9R.png')

    # Get palette and make into Numpy array of 256 entries of 3 RGB colours
    palette = np.array(im.getpalette(),dtype=np.uint8).reshape((256,3))

    # Set palette entry 1 the same as entry 20, and 2 the same as 16
    palette[1] = palette[20]
    palette[2] = palette[16]

    # Change pixels too - this replaces your slow "for" loops
    npim = np.array(im)
    npim[npim==16] = 2
    npim[npim==20] = 1

    # Make Numpy array back into image
    res = Image.fromarray(npim)

    # Apply our modified palette and save
    res.putpalette(palette.ravel().tolist())
    res.save('result.png')

Thanks for the useful hints! Here is my solution:


    df = pd.DataFrame.from_dict({'x' : [0,3,8,7,5,3,2,1],
                                 'y' : [0,1,3,5,9,8,7,5]})
    x = df['x']
    y = df['y']
    # calculate position and direction vectors:
    x0 = x.iloc[range(len(x)-1)].values
    x1 = x.iloc[range(1,len(x))].values
    y0 = y.iloc[range(len(y)-1)].values
    y1 = y.iloc[range(1,len(y))].values
    xpos = (x0+x1)/2
    ypos = (y0+y1)/2
    xdir = x1-x0
    ydir = y1-y0
    fig, ax = plt.subplots()
    ax.scatter(x,y)
    ax.plot(x,y)
    # plot arrow on each line:
    for X,Y,dX,dY in zip(xpos, ypos, xdir, ydir):
        ax.annotate("", xytext=(X,Y),xy=(X+0.001*dX,Y+0.001*dY), 
        arrowprops=dict(arrowstyle="->", color='k'), size = 20)

which gives this:

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

`plt.quiver` does not help in this case, as it creates a field of arrows. `plt.arrow` scales with the axis, so weird looking arrows if x and y units are not the same order of magnitude. Thus, `ax.annotate` was my choice. The arguments `xytext`
& `xy` indicate beginning and end of the arrow respectively.

answers.body_markdown:
As commented, one can use `plt.quiver` to produce arrows along a line, e.g. like

    import numpy as np
    import pandas as pd
    import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
    
    df = pd.DataFrame.from_dict({'x' : [0,3,8,7,5,3,2,1],
                                 'y' : [0,1,3,5,9,8,7,5]})
    x = df['x'].values
    y = df['y'].values
    
    u = np.diff(x)
    v = np.diff(y)
    pos_x = x[:-1] + u/2
    pos_y = y[:-1] + v/2
    norm = np.sqrt(u**2+v**2) 
    
    fig, ax = plt.subplots()
    ax.plot(x,y, marker="o")
    ax.quiver(pos_x, pos_y, u/norm, v/norm, angles="xy", zorder=5, pivot="mid")
    plt.show()

[![enter image description here][1]][1]


  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/zQVuc.png

You could just use arrow annotations to represent the actual line segments like this:

    df = pd.DataFrame.from_dict({'x' : [0,3,8,7,5,3,2,1],
                                 'y' : [0,1,3,5,9,8,7,5]})
    
    for i,row in df.iterrows():
        if i==0:
            pass
        else:
            plt.annotate('',xy=(row['x'],row['y']),xytext=(df.iloc[i-1]['x'],df.iloc[i-1]['y']),
            arrowprops=dict(facecolor='black',width=1,headwidth=5))
                
    plt.xlim(0 ,10)
    plt.ylim(0,10)

> Currently, RNN models using `tf.compat.v1.nn.static_rnn` can be

Also, they provide drop-in replacements for dynamic RNN architectures. See this [section][3]. For the best part, they have provided a [Colab notebook][4]. Also, refer to the [README][5] section.

answers.body_markdown:
I worked this out by identifying 3 types of data that are all smashed into the one data frame, then separating them. Like @jdobres says above, this might not scale beyond this toy example, but should be a start.

From what I can tell, you have 3 types of data that you can pull out based on regex searching in `col1`:

1. Years, identified by `^20\\d{2}$` (will need to be adjusted if you include 19xx years, etc
2. Months, identified by non-digit characters
3. Names, identified either by type of value in `col1` or by non-`NA` `name`

Filter and reshape them so their data matches the shapes shown in your desired output:

<!-- language-all: lang-r -->


    library(dplyr)
    library(tidyr)

    yrs_df <- df %>% 
      filter(grepl("^20\\d{2}$", col1)) %>%
      gather(key, value = year) %>%
      filter(!is.na(year))

    name_df <- df %>%
      filter(!is.na(name)) %>%
      gather(key, value, -name)

The months get reshaped a second time, because you have both `month` and `type` in the same columns, and want to separate them as well.

    month_df <- df %>%
      filter(grepl("^\\D", col1)) %>%
      mutate(col_type = row_number()) %>%
      gather(key, value, -col_type) %>%
      filter(!is.na(value)) %>%
      spread(key = col_type, value, sep = "") %>%
      rename(month = col_type1, type = col_type2)

    yrs_df
    #> # A tibble: 2 x 2
    #>   key   year 
    #>   <chr> <chr>
    #> 1 col1  2017 
    #> 2 col2  2018
    name_df
    #> # A tibble: 4 x 3
    #>   name  key   value
    #>   <chr> <chr> <chr>
    #> 1 dog   col1  10   
    #> 2 cat   col1  30   
    #> 3 dog   col2  20   
    #> 4 cat   col2  50
    month_df
    #> # A tibble: 2 x 3
    #>   key   month type 
    #>   <chr> <chr> <chr>
    #> 1 col1  June  New  
    #> 2 col2  July  Old

Then join everything back by key (could also use `purrr::reduce` since all joins are on the same column)

    yrs_df %>%
      inner_join(month_df, by = "key") %>%
      inner_join(name_df, by = "key")
    #> # A tibble: 4 x 6
    #>   key   year  month type  name  value
    #>   <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr>
    #> 1 col1  2017  June  New   dog   10   
    #> 2 col1  2017  June  New   cat   30   
    #> 3 col2  2018  July  Old   dog   20   
    #> 4 col2  2018  July  Old   cat   50

All that said—there's probably a larger problem here that jumbles up all your data like this that could be solved further upstream.

answers.body_markdown:
I get a 404 when I visit the second link.

For the first link, if you take a look at the html, there are no `<table>`, `<tr>`, or `<td>` HTML tags anywhere. That's because most of the page is wrapped in an `<iframe>`, with the source being https://dealers.mascus.com/semleragro/search.aspx.

If you scrape that instead, you'll have more luck:


    def main():
    
        from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
        import requests
    
        url = "https://dealers.mascus.com/semleragro/search.aspx"
    
        page = requests.get(url)
        soup = BeautifulSoup(page.content, "html.parser")
    
        table = soup.find("table", {"class": "list list_vertical"})
    
        for row in table.find_all("tr", {"class": "item"}):
            cell_2 = row.find("td", {"class": "cell2 cell_brandmodel"})
            title = cell_2.find("a").text
            print(title)
    
        return 0
    
    
    if __name__ == "__main__":
        import sys
        sys.exit(main())


Output:

    Amazone UG3000
    Amazone UG3000
    Hardi 2800 L 20 M TRAILER
    Hardi TZ-TX 2400
    John Deere
    John Deere
    John Deere 732 20M
    John Deere 740 24M
    John Deere 740I TRAILERSPRØJTE
    John Deere 832I
    John Deere 832I
    John Deere M740 TRAILERSPRØJTE
    Kuhn 5600I MARKSPRØJTE
    Kuhn METRIS 4102 24M
    Case IH MXM 190
    Case IH PUMA 230 M/FRONTLIFT
    Case IH PUMA CVX230
    CLAAS AXION 850
    CLAAS XERION 4000
    Deutz 615S

You don't even need pandas for this. Just BeautifulSoup and requests.

EDIT - I've taken a look at this link:

https://www.kragmann.dk/da/brugte-maskiner/entreprenor.html/#/

I'll admit, finding the "source" for this one isn't as straightforward.

The first thing I did is look at what my browser (Chrome) sees when the page is fully rendered. If you have Chrome, you can do this by pressing F12 and looking at the "Elements" tab - and then expand and collapse the HTML-tag tree view as you like. Most modern browsers support a feature like this. In any case, what you see in this tree view is not necessarily the same as what you would see just looking at the raw HTML source code, since this view is made up of all HTML elements, including the ones that are generated dynamically by JavaScript or by other means. Here's what I saw in the tree view:

[![][1]][1]

The individual "ads" (vehicles for sale) are under the "external-wrapper" div, which is under the "usedMachines" div. The fact that the div is called "external-wrapper" is a clue that it's contents are being generated by some script.

Then I took a look at the actual source code of the page (in Chrome, right-click -> "View page source") - it looks different from what we just saw in the tree view:

[![][2]][2]

I can see the "usedMachines" div, but the "external-wrapper" div is not there. As suspected, it is being generated using JavaScript and JQuery. Normally, this is where I would suggest you use Selenium, but I dug a little deeper.

Just above the "usedMachines" div, there is a `<script>` tag, which looks like this:

`<script src="https://lister.maskinbladet.dk/system/data/loader3.js" type="text/javascript"></script>`
Taking a look at the source code for that JavaScript file, at the very top, you can see some interesting variables, such as:

`basePath = 'https://lister.maskinbladet.dk/system/data/'`
Visiting that URL gives me a 403 error. The page informs me that my access was denied because I didn't submit the correct credentials. Fortunately, we can see in the JavaScript some of the payload keys (GET-parameters) it expects to see:

    defaultConfig = {
            type: 'normal',
            count: '1',
            callbackURL: '',
            fncallback: '',
            hashtype: 'normal',
            showall: false,
            fbshare: false
    ...

I'd like to scrape this basePath url. So, now I have a url, and I know that I'll have to spoof my credentials and GET-parameters. Looking down a little further I see this:

`ajaxUrl = basePath+'jsonp3.php',`

Which is good to know. This is the actual url we want to scrape.
The code then goes on populating a `ident` dictionary/map (short for "identity" I'm guessing) with GET-parameters. You could try to reverse-engineer the whole thing to get the final list of GET-parameters, but it's easier to just grab them from Chrome's resource log, which I'll do in a bit.

We're almost done looking at the JavaScript - one more interesting snippet is the following: I was just curious to see where `ajaxUrl` ends up being used - namely in this function:

    function JSONajax(attr, callBack) {
        jQuery.ajax({
            url: ajaxUrl, type: 'GET', data: attr, dataType: 'jsonp'
        })
        .done(function(data){
            if (typeof(callBack) === 'function') callBack.call(this, data);
        });
    }

It looks like this function accepts two parameters, `attr` and `callback`. The function then makes a GET request to our `ajaxUrl`, and passes `attr` along with the request. That tells me the first parameter must be some kind of collection of payload- or credential key-value pairs. It then binds the second parameter, which is a function, as a callback to be triggered when a response is received. If you search the JavaScript for "JSONajax", you will be able to confirm that the `ident` dictionary/map is passed in as the first argument, which is just more proof that the `ajaxUrl` is the url we want to scrape.

Now I just need to spoof my credentials and GET-parameters. In Chrome, hit F12 and then open the "Network" tab. I then started recording the network traffic and refreshed the page. I looked for "jsonp3.php", and the log shows this request-response history:

[![][3]][3]

Which reveals all GET-parameters in the request url. A little further down we also get our credentials and a prettier view of the GET-parameters. How convenient!

[![][4]][4]

All that's left to do is to write a python script to do the actual scraping, which looks something like this:


    def main():
    
        from bs4 import BeautifulSoup
        import requests
    
        base_path = "https://lister.maskinbladet.dk/system/data/"
        ajax_url = base_path + "jsonp3.php"
        headers = {
            "Referer": "https://www.kragmann.dk/da/brugte-maskiner/entreprenor.html/",
            "Sec-Fetch-Mode": "no-cors",
            "User-Agent": "Mozilla/5.0"
        }
        params = {
            "callback": "jQuery112409740978028988687_1570979614706",
            "locationGUID": "E3EBC2C4-A913-4B75-8918-3BFC7851EF31",
            "version": "adlist",
            "count": "1",
            "showall": "true",
            "fbshare": "false",
            "showyh": "false",
            "pager": "false",
            "contact": "false",
            "noPrice": "false",
            "prefix": "true",
            "orderbyBrand": "false",
            "languageGUID": "63927773-3f10-4874-b08f-823e9aa456ee",
            "currencyGUID": "51597510-a206-4353-ae21-ce8d648fe948",
            "treeGUID": "f268d600-625f-4650-ab91-b3cfef4c9f0d",
            "_": "1570979614707"
        }
    
        response = requests.get(ajax_url, headers=headers, params=params)
        assert response.status_code == 200
        
        # Unfortunately, the response isn't raw HTML - there is HTML but it's encapsulated by JQuery stuff...
        text = response.text[response.text.index("<div"):-4].replace("\\", "")
        soup = BeautifulSoup(text, "html.parser")
    
        for ad in soup.find_all("div", {"class": "ad-detail"}):
    
            attributes = ["brand", "model", "price"]
            infos = []
    
            for attribute in attributes:
                try:
                    info = ad.find("div", {"class": f"ad-{attribute}"}).text
                    assert info
                    infos.append(info)
                except (AttributeError, AssertionError):
                    infos.append("N/A")
    
            for attribute, info in zip(attributes, infos):
                print(f"{attribute}: {info}")
            print()
    
        return 0
    
    
    if __name__ == "__main__":
        import sys
        sys.exit(main())

answers.body_markdown:
As per [Understanding WS-Federation — Passive Requestor Profile][1] article:

> 1. The requester accesses the resource.

> 2. If no session tracking token (or cookie, that identifies the request as belonging to an authenticated session) is provided in the request, the resource redirects the requestor to the resource’s IdP/STS.

> 3. If the resource’s IdP/STS has not cached data indicating that the requestor has already been authenticated (another cookie most like), a second redirection to the requestor’s IdP/STS will be performed to authenticate the user.

> 4. If information about the user’s IdP/STS or home realm is not provided in the request, the 
IdP/STS may have to prompt the user for realm information or utilize some type of Home Realm Discovery Service. Afterwards, the user is redirected to the authentication workflow.

> 5. The user is prompted for credentials, the credentials are submitted to the requestor’s IdP/STS and the those credentials are validated.

> 6. The requestor’s IdP/STS generates a security token for use by the federated party.

> 7. The requestor IdP/STS-generated token is passed back to the resource’s IdP/STS to exchange for a token scoped to the resource.

> 8. The resource’s IdP/STS passes the new token to the resource via HTTP redirect.

> 9. The resource consumes the token and builds a security context.

> 10. The requester is redirected to the resource URL.

Therefore getting the token is a matter of implementing [correlation][2] of the token after you provided the credentials to the ADFS gateway, the token can be fetched using a suitable JMeter's [Post-Processor][3] and you should replace recorded hard-coded token which has limited time to live with the [JMeter Variable][4] coming from the Post-Processor. 


  [1]: https://medium.com/@robert.broeckelmann/understanding-ws-federation-passive-protocol-3f9dc2175b4f
  [2]: https://www.blazemeter.com/blog/advanced-load-testing-scenarios-jmeter-part-1-correlations/
  [3]: https://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/component_reference.html#postprocessors
  [4]: https://jmeter.apache.org/usermanual/functions.html

answers.body_markdown:
> both links fail to mention whether an `inline` variables are inline in sense that they could be inlined by the compiler just like inline functions.

Most likely that is because there is no reason to mention such a thing. You are basing your expectation on a false premise. The `inline` keyword has no bearing on whether or not a function can be inlined by the compiler. A compiler can choose to inline functions not marked `inline`, and it can choose to not inline functions marked `inline`. This has been the case from the beginning, even when the `inline` keyword was first introduced. 

There was a time when the `inline` keyword was a hint to the compiler, but even then it was only a hint. The compiler was always free to make its own decisions about which functions to inline. Since that time, compilers have become better than programmers when it comes to deciding which functions are efficient to inline. So most modern compilers ignore the supposed hint (at full optimization).


> that is replaced with the actual value on call site.

This cannot be done in general. A function call can be replaced by the function's content (its body) by the compiler because the compiler knows what the function's content is. In contrast, a variable's content (its value) is not known by the compiler. That is, after all, often the point of declaring a variable. Since the compiler does not know the "actual value", there is no way for the compiler to use that value as a replacement for fetching the value from the variable's location in memory.

This can be done, though, in the specific case where the compiler can deduce what the value of the variable will be. As with functions, it is up to the compiler to decide whether to use that value directly in the machine instructions or to retrieve that value from the variable's memory location. The use of keywords has no bearing on this decision (although at full optimizations, I would expect the value to be used as long as it fits in a register). The only keyword that is relevant is [`constexpr`](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/language/constexpr), which makes it much easier for the compiler to deduce what the value of the variable will be.

Because your download method is called in `cellForRow` this will fetch every time a new cell is going to be dequeued. 

I would suggest doing the download in `viewDidLoad()` and save the downloaded images into an array which your cell can reference. When the download is finished you can tell your collection view to reload its data. 

If you do not want to download the images every time you see the screen you will need to persist the downloaded image data and then you can access that instead of calling download in `viewDidLoad()`.

	Private Sub btn_Save_Click(ByVal Sender As Object, ByVal e As EventArgs) Handles btn_Save.Click

answers.body_markdown:
Don't mix notations/standards.  To add category, simply inner join category to your production table.  This assumes all productions will have a category; otherwise you may want to left (outer) join.


    create view salesView as 
    SELECT o.oID
         , p.name as product
         , c.name as category
         , od.sell_price as price
         , od.qty as quantity
         , o.order_date
         , c.name
    FROM orderDetails od 
    INNER JOIN orders o 
       on o.oID = od.oID
    INNER JOIN Production p 
       on p.ID = od.pID
    INNER JOIN Category c
       on c.ID = P.catID
    WHERE...

Don't do this:

    create view salesView as select o.oID, p.name as product, od.sell_price as price, od.qty as quantity, o.order_date
        from orderDetails od inner join --<See the inner join
        orders o on o.oID = od.oID, --<See the ,  (don't mix standards!)
        production p where = p.ID = od.pID;

Notice the difference in standards: https://gerardnico.com/data/type/relation/sql/join_default_ansi92_comparison

Well maybe because we don't want an overhead of building a relay server from scratch where there are some good and free implementation like [coturn][1] and [restund][2]. You'll need to spend quite a lot of time achieving same level of performance and scalability.

Also, with a TURN server in place, you don't need a separate STUN server.

answers.body_markdown:
Usually socket.io and Node is used for signaling (and sending custom messages) only. A simple CoTurn instance can run on a 5$ vps.

Besided the use as a turn server it also offers stun functionality, but in my experience it's always a good idea to also use the public google STUN (Except in China, it's not reachable).

The question is: Have you checked the network and system load with your implementation and compared it to a classical TURN setup?
answers.title: WebRTC: how does a TURN server differ from rolling your own custom server that passes communication through?

items.body_markdown:
In understanding WebRTC, I found one thing difficult to understand about TURN servers. Let me quickly recap what I do understand.

**A signaling server:** is a custom (non-protocol specified) implementation of passing SDP packets to negotiate a WebRTC connection. The most fun/wacky implementation is where you copy/paste SDP packets in as plain text as explained by [Chris Ball][1] (sidenote: who said "implementation" means that you have to program something? :-D ).

**A STUN server:** it tells you your reachable IP + port. Bye bye NAT! Oh, only in 80% of the cases.

The other 20%, my understanding of **TURN servers** is: a server reachable for both (or more) P2P connecting parties that relays data from those parties through the TURN server (Traversal Using Relays Around Nat) and sends it to the other party. It is described in [RFC 5766][2].

**My situation** (and the question that results from it)

 1. I have a signalling server (yay!)
 2. I have a STUN server (hurray!)
 3. I have a NodeJS server running with Socket.io for when P2P fails via the signalling and STUN server. It simply gets incoming traffic and broadcasts it to whomever needs to listen in.

I know that my server is a custom-built thing that achieves the same thing as a TURN server would. 

**My question**: *how is such a custom-built server different when compared to a TURN server?*

**Note**: in my case it's NodeJS + Socket.io, but it could be any custom-built server (for fun, I also created a Ruby/Rails implementation with WebSockets without HTTP long polling as a fallback).

  [1]: https://blog.printf.net/articles/2013/05/17/webrtc-without-a-signaling-server/
  [2]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5766

Can anyone offer any suggestions of things to try?

answers.body_markdown:
> [Errno 2] No such file or directory

There is actually no such file or directory as `Mick_compose.yml` in the default directory where your command is launched. To fix that, I could show you how to change dir from the [command module](https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/command_module.html) to the correct one holding your file.

But I will let you discover that on your own (if you still really want to do it after this explanation) because you should not run commands directly when there is an [existing ansible module already doing what you need](https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/docker_compose_module.html)
```
- name: Make sure compose service is up
  docker_compose:
    project_src: /path/to/your/compose/project
    files:
      - "{{ name }}_compose.yml"
    state: present
```
This is just to put you on track, have a look at the module doc link above for more info on the possible parameters.
answers.title: Execute docker-compose inside Ansible playbook

answers.body_markdown:
Directory where playbook runs doesn't contain the `{{ name }}_compose.yml` file.
 
There's [relevant module][1] which can help you.
If you don't want to use it, you can add task which will show the directory where playbook runs: 

    - name: copy sql schema
      hosts: test-mysql
      gather_facts: no
      tasks:
        - debug: 
            msg: "{{ playbook_dir }}"
        - name: Docker compose
          command: docker-compose -f {{ name }}_compose.yml up -d

Then, either move `{{ name }}_compose.yml` to the directory or provide an absolute path in command: `docker-compose -f [abs_path]{{ name }}_compose.yml up -d`


  [1]: https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/docker_compose_module.html
answers.title: Execute docker-compose inside Ansible playbook

    DB::statement("ALTER TABLE skillsdb.users ADD CONSTRAINT chk_password_null CHECK (COALESCE(password, '') <> '' OR is_sso)");

And that works wonderfully. However, the problem is in the "down()" part of the migration. This statement throws errors:

    DB::statement("ALTER TABLE skillsdb.users DROP CONSTRAINT chk_password_null");

Even though copy/pasting that query directly into my PostgresQL console works as intended. Here's the exact error:

    Rolling back: 2019_10_11_124350_add_sso_users
    
    In Connection.php line 664:
    
      SQLSTATE[42704]: Undefined object: 7 ERROR:  constraint "chk_password_null"
       of relation "users" does not exist (SQL: ALTER TABLE skillsdb.users DROP C
      ONSTRAINT chk_password_null)
    
    
    In PDOStatement.php line 119:
    
      SQLSTATE[42704]: Undefined object: 7 ERROR:  constraint "chk_password_null"
       of relation "users" does not exist
    
    
    In PDOStatement.php line 117:
    
      SQLSTATE[42704]: Undefined object: 7 ERROR:  constraint "chk_password_null"
       of relation "users" does not exist

To be clear, I've triple-checked the constraint *does* exist, and that the rollback query works when passed directly to postgres. Any idea why artisan begs to differ?

  [1]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/38223158/laravel-migration-adding-check-constraints-in-table

items.body_markdown:
# 1 The problem

I want to use PowerPivot to calculate conditional percentiles of my data, where the order of operation is to **FIRST** calculate some **sums per subgroups** and **THEN** to compute **percentiles per groups**.


# 2 The Setup 
I have a table with investment portfolios, instruments, scenarios and prices like so

    Portfolio  | Stock| SCENARIO   | ProfitLoss
    A          | GOOG | 1          | -50 USD
    A          | GOOG | 2          | +90 USD
    ...        | ...  | ...        | ...
    A          | GOOG | 100        | -70 USD
    B          | AAPL | 1          | +13 USD
    B          | AAPL | 2          | +12 USD
    ...        | ...  | ...        | ...
    B          | AAPL | 100        |  +9 USD
    B          | GOOG | 1          | ...
    ...        | ...  | ...        | ...


Depending on the level of analysis (i.e. on the level of a single stock, a single portfolio or across all portfolios and stocks) I want to calculate the **Percentile** measure by first aggregating the column ProfitLoss per scenario and **then ** take the quantile. 

## Examples 

**Example 1**: Find the 99% quantile profit/loss for the **whole book**:

1. For each scenario, sum the ProfitLoss column over all portfolios and stocks. Again, this results in a single "vector" of length 100 and find its 99% quantile.

**Example 2**: Find the 99% quantile of ProfitLoss **per portfolio**

1. For each scenario, sum the ProfitLoss column across all stocks in each portfolio. This results in multiple "vectors" each with 100 entries.

2. For each portfolio, Find the 99% percentile of its corresponding data.

**Example 3**: Find the 99% quantile of ProfitLoss for each stock:

1. For each scenario, sum the ProfitLoss Column over all Portfolios for each stock. Again, this results in "vectors" with 100 rows.

2. Find the 99% percentile of each "vector"

# Tried so far

As I am quite new to the DAX language, it is very hard for me to wrap my head around level-of-detail calculations / filter expressions and such. Except for one slightly related post on SO (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46071807/dax-percentiles-of-sums) (which also does not really seem to work for me?), I have not found any sensible solution - and would be quite thankful for any pointer to a ressource / solution.
items.title: Find percentiles of sums using DAX
